channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment

item.title: Stopping the Greatest Threat to the Amazon, One Fire at a Time
item.description: After four decades of research, a scientist returns to the Amazon in an effort to change the behavior that has led to years of environmental crisis.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Dado Galdieri
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times

item.title: In One Week, Trump Moves to Reshape U.S. Environmental Policy
item.description: The Trump administration this week moved to weaken the Clean Water Act and the Endangered Species Act, two bedrock laws, among other deregulatory moves.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in Washington this week. A series of proposed rollbacks could reshape U.S. environmental policy for years to come.

item.title: China Offers Panda Totes, but No New Commitments, at Climate Talks
item.description: The United States has retreated on climate. China, the only superpower at COP30 and the world leader in clean energy, is not filling the void.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Adriano Machado/Reuters
item.media:description: The China pavilion of the COP30 conference in Belém, Brazil, last week.

item.title: Lemurs in Madagascar Face an Unexpected Killer
item.description: Thousands of the endangered primates end up on the dinner plates of people in the upper rung of the country’s society who have money to spare.
item.dc:creator: Dina Fine Maron
item.media:credit: Cortni Borgerson
item.media:description: A bamboo lemur (Hapalemur occidentalis) eating bamboo.

item.title: COP30 Climate Summit Ends With Dire Warnings and Scant Plans for Action
item.description: The final agreement, with no direct mention of the fossil fuels dangerously heating Earth, was a victory for countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia, diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Pablo Porciuncula/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The closing session of the COP30 climate negotiations in Belém, Brazil, on Saturday.

item.title: A Colossal, Hidden Pile of Trash Ignites an Outcry in Britain
item.description: The discovery of a mountain of garbage near a highway is the latest example of what experts say is a growing problem of criminal organizations profiting from illegal dumping.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A large pile of illegally dumped waste accumulated next to the River Cherwell near Kidlington, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Fine Chocolate in Brazil, Home of the Cacao Bean
item.description: A new generation of craft chocolate makers in Brazil is creating bars with “identity.” And they’re helping to sustain the forest, too.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Alessandro Falco

item.title: Energy Department Reorganization Reflects Shift Away From Renewable Energy
item.description: The reorganization reflects the ongoing shift in the federal government’s energy priorities: less renewable energy, more fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy and the Office of Clean Energy Demonstrations no longer appear in an organizational chart posted by the Energy Department on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Plans to Open More Than a Billion Acres of U.S. Waters to Drilling
item.description: The plan from the Interior Department is one of the president’s most significant steps yet to increase domestic fossil fuel production.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Oil industry vessels moored at Port Fourchon, La., on the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: Home Prices on a Warming Planet
item.description: New research shows that climate change is beginning to erode home prices in the most disaster-prone areas of the United States. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown and Mira Rojanasakul
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding in Lafitte, La., after Hurricane Ida in 2021. Places that are most vulnerable to climate-related disasters like hurricanes, fires and hail are seeing some of the largest premium increases.

item.title: Fire Breaks Out at COP30 Climate Talks in Brazil
item.description: Delegates were evacuated from the conference venue, where thousands from nearly 200 countries had gathered.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video taken on Thursday at the COP30 climate talks in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: As the World Pursues Clean Power, Millions Still Have No Power at All
item.description: Just outside Belém, the Amazonian city where the world is meeting to discuss climate change, electricity is a very recent arrival.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Alessandro Falco
item.media:credit: Alessandro Falco for The New York Times

item.title: She Studied How to Protect Children From Pollution and Heat
item.description: “There was no warning, no conversation,” said Jane Clougherty, an environmental health scientist, who had a federal grant canceled earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Moves to Weaken the Endangered Species Act
item.description: Four proposed rules could make it easier to drill for oil or harvest timber in areas where endangered species live.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: David Goldman/Associated Press
item.media:description: An endangered red wolf in the Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge near Manns Harbor, N.C., in 2023.

item.title: Trump Wanted to Abolish FEMA. His Own Advisers Disagree.
item.description: A panel convened by President Trump is said to have rejected the president’s idea that the agency should “go away.”
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, during a news conference with Texas officials following the catastrophic flooding of the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas, in July.

item.title: The Climate Is Changing, Cows Are Stressed and Italy’s Cheesemakers Are Worried
item.description: Extreme heat causes cows to produce less milk. This poses problems in cheese-obsessed Italy, especially as it tries to meet growing demand for favorites like burrata.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Gianni Cipriano

item.title: In Nebraska, Makeovers for Buildings That Don’t Price Out the Locals
item.description: In a struggling area of Lincoln, a program pays for repairs and energy efficiency upgrades in rental buildings. In return, landlords must keep rents affordable.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Arin Yoon
item.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: They Loved Their Family Land in South Carolina. But Who Actually Owned It?
item.description: Conservation can be tough when a property is passed down informally over generations. A growing effort is helping families sort it all out.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Nora Williams
item.media:credit: Nora Willams For The New York Times

item.title: Driving an E.V. Across North Dakota? Thank the Standing Rock Tribe.
item.description: A tribally owned network of chargers will soon be complete, connecting reservations and bridging a gap in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Jaida Grey Eagle
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times

item.title: In Washington, Birds Are Giving ‘Yelp Reviews’ of Forest Restoration Work
item.description: A collective of land trusts, conservancies and tribes is capturing birdsong with audio gear and A.I. for clues about habitat health.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Meron Menghistab
item.media:credit: Meron Menghistab for The New York Times

item.title: Iowa City Made Its Buses Free. Traffic Cleared, and So Did the Air.
item.description: Ridership jumped, people cut back on driving and, over the summer, the city extended the program another year.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Annick Sjobakken
item.media:credit: Annick Sjobakken for The New York Times

item.title: Frustrated With Your Home Insurer? Tell Us About It.
item.description: Help us track trends in the home insurance market by filling out this survey.
item.dc:creator: Mira Rojanasakul and Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Climate-Friendly’ Beef Now Has to Prove It
item.description: Two new settlements could change how the beef industry markets its products and require that it provide proof for its pledges to lower emissions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cattle on a feedlot in Brazil, where JBS, the beef giant, is headquartered.

item.title: Environmentalists Sue to Stop Oil Lease Sales in the Gulf of Mexico
item.description: A Trump administration proposal to allow more exploration for oil and gas violates environmental laws, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil operation in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: The Future of Energy Has Arrived — Just Not in the U.S.
item.description: While China is selling clean energy to the world, America is pushing oil and gas.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams, David Gelles, Brad Plumer, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Nina Feldman, Caitlin O’Keefe, Chris Haxel, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Will Reid and Alyssa Moxley
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A solar farm in China. More wind turbines and solar panels were installed in the country last year than in the rest of the world combined.

item.title: Greenpeace Faces an Unusual New Legal Attack From a Pipeline Giant
item.description: The company that won a huge verdict against Greenpeace earlier this year has asked a North Dakota court to block a countersuit in the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Robyn Beck/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline project near Cannonball, N.D., in September 2016. Earlier this year a court found Greenpeace liable for its role in demonstrations there.

item.title: Study Analyzes How Much ‘Macro’ Plastic Is Deadly to Sea Life
item.description: Scientists analyzed thousands of autopsies of seabirds, sea turtles and marine mammals and found that even small amounts of ingested plastic can be deadly.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Kamran Jebreili/Associated Press
item.media:description: An autopsied Hawksbill sea turtle in a lab in the United Arab Emirates. Lying beside the turtle are items removed from its stomach, including a large amount of plastic.

item.title: E.P.A. Drastically Limits Protections for Wetlands
item.description: The proposal could strip federal protections from most U.S. wetlands, some of which feed drinking water systems.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Madeline Gray for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new definition could strip federal protections from up to 55 million acres of wetlands, or about 85 percent of all wetlands nationwide.

item.title: David Richardson, Acting FEMA Administration, Resigns
item.description: David Richardson had been on the job for six months. FEMA employees had questioned his ability to lead the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: David Richardson, acting administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, in July.

item.title: A Plan for Private Jet Taxes Would Fund Climate Measures
item.description: A small group of countries is aiming to impose a fee on private jets and premium commercial fares. The revenue would help nations adapt to warming.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Neil Hall/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A private jet at the Farnborough International Airshow last year. Aviation accounts for roughly 4 percent of greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: We Can Now Track Individual Monarch Butterflies. It’s a Revelation.
item.description: Scientists used tiny new sensors to follow the insects on journeys that take thousands of miles to their winter colonies in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Dan Fagin and Jonathan Corum
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Thousands March for Climate Action as COP30 Talks Enter Second Week
item.description: As the talks continue, some countries are pushing for a detailed “road map” for a global transition away from oil, gas and coal.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Brad Plumer and Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andre Penner/Associated Press
item.media:description: A demonstration near the U.N. climate summit in Belém, Brazil, on Saturday. The atmosphere has been a marked contrast to the past three summits that were held in countries where governments restricted public protests.

item.title: What Should I Do With My Playbill?
item.description: Readers ask about the most environmentally friendly thing to do with an unwanted program. And by the way, why is it always yellow?
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

item.title: Hydropower Is Getting Less Reliable as the World Needs More Energy
item.description: Demand for power is growing fast, but hydro plants, the oldest source of clean energy, are struggling because of droughts, floods and other extreme weather linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Your Questions About Climate Change, Answered
item.description: You asked Somini Sengupta, our international climate reporter, about the science and the politics. She responded from COP30 in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Adriano Machado/Reuters

item.title: UN Climate Summit in Brazil Brings Tourism and Change to Belém’s Ver-o-Peso Market
item.description: A market central to a Brazilian port city’s culture and cuisine got a makeover for the U.N. Climate Change Conference. The results have thrilled some but angered others.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors in the Ver-o-Peso market serving fish and açaí to customers at newly renovated booths in the food sector in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: Women Toiling in India’s Insufferable Heat Face Mounting Toll on Health
item.description: Prolonged exposure to hot weather can hinder people’s ability to lead safe and productive lives, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Anindito Mukherjee
item.media:description: A worker from the Self‑Employed Women’s Association monitoring the blood pressure of Arti Chuhan, a tailor, last month in Ahmedabad, India.

item.title: How Many People Die in India From Hot Weather? Nobody Really Knows.
item.description: Officials have yet to grasp the magnitude of heat-related deaths, let alone effectively deal with the problem, public health experts and scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Anindito Mukherjee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters drinking water from canisters placed near a bus stand during a heat wave in Rajasthan, India, in June.

item.title: Hochul Urged to Ban Horseshoe Crab Fishing
item.description: Supporters of the legislation argue it would protect a declining horseshoe crab population, while opponents warn it will harm the commercial fishing industry.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Gov. Kathy Hochul signs the bill, New York would join New Jersey and Connecticut in stopping the fishing industry from using the crabs as bait for catching other marine species, including the endangered American eel.

item.title: Indigenous People Take the Stage at COP30 Climate Talks in Belém, Brazil
item.description: This summit is unlike any of its predecessors in at least one significant way: The Indigenous presence is palpable and strong.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta, Brad Plumer and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Mauro Pimentel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Indigenous rights demonstration on Thursday in Belém, Brazil. The snake in the background was a prop with a meaning.

item.title: An Escape From India’s Air Pollution for Those Who Can Afford It
item.description: Companies are offering much-needed, but expensive, air purification systems to shelter from the smog in one of the world’s most polluted cities.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers assembling YOGA Clean Air units in a factory in Greater Noida, Uttar Pradesh in India.

item.title: Trump Administration Revokes Biden Ban on Drilling and Mining in Alaska Wilderness
item.description: The decision to allow oil and gas drilling in Alaska’s ecologically sensitive North Slope has the support of the state’s governor and senators.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Caribou near a pipeline on the north slope of Alaska in 2023.

item.title: The Dogs of 8,000 B.C. Were Amazingly Diverse
item.description: The staggering array of modern dog breeds is typically traced to the Victorian era. But half of all canine variation was in place roughly 10,000 years ago, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: The Global Climate Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The United States is largely absent from the United Nations climate negotiations in Brazil. So who is stepping up?
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Fernando Llano/Associated Press
item.media:description: A lobby of the COP30 United Nations climate summit in Belém, Brazil.

item.title: Bird Flu Ravaged the World’s Largest Elephant Seal Population, Study Finds
item.description: After the H5N1 virus hit the remote island of South Georgia in 2023, more than 50,000 breeding females may have disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms
item.description: Austin Becker developed an early warning system to protect critical infrastructure from storms. His project’s funding was eliminated in April.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Kannetha Brown for The New York Times

item.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
item.description: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Diego Vara/Reuters
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Candiota, in southeastern Brazil.

item.title: U.K. Gives Go-Ahead to Smaller Nuclear Reactor in Wales
item.description: The government pledged 2.5 billion pounds for initial site work, but the decision to build a small, modular design may disappoint others, including the U.S. nuclear industry.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wylfa 1 nuclear power plant, in Wales in 2018. The 1960s-era facility shut down a decade ago.

item.title: China’s Green Triumph
item.description: China is equipping other countries to fight climate change. It’s a role reversal.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A solar panel factory in Suqian, China.
